Result.Title: Katrina's Fury
Result.Summary: Early this morning, Hurricane Katrina slammed into the Gulf coast with 145mph winds. Full size image showing three reporter's locations available when you're logged into Flickr. Related blog post: a href= http://refreshbox.com/blog/2005/08/keeping-your-head.html target= _blank Keeping your head /a . Photo Credit: a href= http://www.nasa.gov/vision/earth/lookingatearth/h2005_katrina.html target= _blank NASA /a .

Result.Title: Hurricane Katrina HD 655
Result.Summary: A man clings to the top of a vehicle before being rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard from the flooded streets of New Orleans, in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, in Louisiana September 4, 2005. The death toll has continued to rise as people succumbed to illness and exhaustion while waiting for help, but the evacuation picked up speed over the weekend with tens of thousands of people being moved to temporary shelters in Louisiana and Texas. REUTERS/Robert Galbraith For more quot;AUTHORISED quot; High definition photos of this disaster, in a medium WITHOUT ADD'S, POP-UP'S etc featuring 100s of satellite photos and relief efforts photos please visit: a href= http://www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 /a Archive contains over 20,000 images!

Result.Title: Hurricane Katrina
Result.Summary: As an oil depot burns itself to the ground, serious questions about incompetent civil defense should be raised to the a href= http://irish.typepad.com/irisheyes/2005/09/under_katrina.html federal level /a . (Image from AP and a href= http://news.yahoo.com/photos/ss/441 Yahoo Editor's Picks /a .)

Result.Title: Katrina's Waves
Result.Summary: Waves kicked up by Hurricane Katrina -- roaring ashore 350 miles (564 kilometers) away in New Orleans -- break against the 45th street jetty on Monday.

Result.Title: Katrina Devistation 0500901-N-0000X-002
Result.Summary: 050901-N-0000X-002 Gulfport, Miss. (Sept. 1, 2005) РThe family housing area on board Naval Construction Battalion Center (NCBC) Gulfport, Miss., shows considerable damage from Hurricane Katrina. NCBC functions as a support for operating units of the Naval Construction Force. It supports various Naval Mobile Construction battalions, the Naval Construction Training Center and other smaller tenant activities. A Category 4 hurricane, Katrina came ashore on Aug. 29 near the Louisiana bayou town of Buras. U.S. Navy photo (RELEASED) For more quot;AUTHORISED quot; High definition photos of this disaster, satellite photos and relief efforts photos please visit: a href= http://www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 /a

Result.Title: Princess and Timmy saved
Result.Summary: This is not my picture. It is from the AP. I uploaded it because it struck me profoundly. With all the things in this world, for them all they wanted to save were their pets, no heirlooms, no suitcases or bags of stuff, just two tiny dogs named Princess held by Adeline Perkins (in the foreground) and Timmy held by Lynell Batiste. While the Red Cross helps people, there are thousands of animals who people had to leave behind. Also the Red Cross does not allow pets in their shelters so they work together with other groups. Here are two good site that does animals rescues and houses them after natural disasters, which along with the Red Cross, our family donated to: a href= http://news.bestfriends.org/index.cfm?page=specialreports amp;mode=cat amp;catid=04061773-BDB9-396E-9001EF6EC01318A4 news.bestfriends.org/index.cfm?page=specialreports amp;mo... /a a href= http://www.uan.org/ears/action_report.html www.uan.org/ears/action_report.html /a The picture above illustrates that these people love their animals more than anything in the world. I told my cats that if anything like this happened to us, we would never leave them behind. They just meowed at me and rolled over on their backs wanting to be scratched. here is the source picture a href= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9133876/displaymode/1107/s/1/framenumber/5/var1/btn_4 www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9133876/displaymode/1107/s/1/framenu... /a

Result.Title: Hurricane Katrina Photos, 050831-N-8154G-198
Result.Summary: 050831-N-8154G-198 New Orleans, La. (Aug 31, 2005) РA man carries a baby through the flooded streets of New Orleans outside the cities Super Dome football stadium. Tens of thousands of displaced citizens sought shelter at the dome, before, during and after Hurricane Katrina, but have been forced to evacuate as floodwaters continue to rise throughout the area. U.S. Navy photo by Photographer's Mate Airman Jeremy L. Grisham (RELEASED) To see more Ultra High Definition photos of this disaster please visit: a href= http://www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 www.photoduck.com/photos.aspx?gid=2681 amp;pxo=0 /a

Result.Title: Yahoo! News: Three coffins that had floated out of the crypts...
Result.Summary: p Three coffins that had floated out of the crypts they were entombed in during Hurricane Katrina await re-interment in the Tropical Bend cemetery in Empire, Louisiana November 11, 2005. While the eye of Hurricane Katrina missed New Orleans it passed directly over Plaquemines Parish bringing with it a storm surge that scattered coffins, tombs, and human remains from dozens of cemeteries in the region. /p

Result.Title: Yahoo! News: **FILE PHOTO** A wheelchair with a slipper still...
Result.Summary: p **FILE PHOTO** A wheelchair with a slipper still on the footrest sits in the mud left by Hurricane Katrina at St. Rita's Nursing Home in St. Bernard, La., Sept. 16, 2005. /p
JOHN VAN BEEKUM, KRT A ferry and shrimp boat sit grounded in Pascagoula.

Result.Title: Yahoo! News: Hurricane Katrina evacuees in Houston, Texas
Result.Summary: p Hurricane Katrina evacuees gather outside the Reliant Center in Houston, Texas September 2005. Authorities in Texas are looking for hundreds of wanted criminals, including scores of sex offenders, who fled Louisiana after hurricanes Katrina and Rita hit the southern US coast, officials said /p

Result.Title: Hurricane Katrina to cost Lloyd's 1.9 billion pounds
Result.Summary: Lloyd's, the world's biggest insurance underwriting market, raised its estimated pre-tax loss from Hurricane Katrina to 1.9 billion pounds (2.8 billion euros, 3.3 billion dollars) from 1.4 billion.

Result.Title: Yahoo! News: Coffin that had almost floated out of the crypts...
Result.Summary: p A coffin that had almost floated out of the crypts it was entombed in during Hurricane Katrina awaits re-interment in the Tropical Bend cemetery in Empire, Louisiana November 11, 2005. While the eye of Hurricane Katrina missed New Orleans it passed directly over Plaquemines Parish bringing with it a storm surge that scattered coffins, tombs, and human remains from dozens of cemeteries in the region. /p

Result.Title: We Are, Still
Result.Summary: This is what is left of someones front yard. Behind this the house is almost completely collapsed. There is pretty much nothing left for these people, yet....they still showed all of us, in the midst of all this destruction, their spirt and faith. I cant tell yall how much the people of Mississippi affected me. They are proud and strong people. They had signs, in what used to be their yards, their homes completely gone, thanking people for helping them. How amazing. They have nothing left, yet it was important to make this huge sign thanking rescuers, volunteers, etc. I have never been hugged and thanked so much by strangers. These communities will return, stronger than ever I believe. They have faith in themselves and so do I. Please take a look at how Lucid Nightmare took this picture and made a special photo for me to remember. So very awesome. a href= http://www.flickr.com/photos/lucid_nightmare/44564700/?#comment12111615 www.flickr.com/photos/lucid_nightmare/44564700/?#comment1... /a There are so many amazing people in this world.Tthis nightmare brought out the worst in alot of people and the media sure made sue we heard about them. I hope to spread the word about the amazing people i have come across that were affected by Katrina. I also want everyone to know the special people on Flickr that have touched my life. Thank yall.

Result.Title: Hurricane Katrina, Sunday 7 am EDT
Result.Summary: This is the current satellite image from the a href= http://www.goes.noaa.gov/GIFS/GULFIR.JPG NOAA /a website, as of Sunday, August 28, 7am EDT. a href= http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/refresh/graphics_at2+shtml/204748.shtml?3day?large Here /a is the actual predicted path of the storm. Early this morning the storm was upgraded to a category 5 on a scale of 1-5, with 5 being the strongest. Currently the winds reach 160 mph (260 kmh), with gusts up to 195 mph. The predicted landfall will be around New Orleans on Monday. The city is currently being evacuated, as it lays several feet under sea level. Residents who stay, are advised to seek shelter in at least the third floor of buildings. Expected rainfall from the very slow moving storm is 15 inches, the storm surge from the Gulf of Mexico is expected to reach 25 feet (8m). In SW Florida life is normal again. The sun is shining and people are playing golf as usual. We hold our breath and pray for everybody in the path of monster storm Katrina. Stay safe, y'all! (For locations see notes on the a href= http://www.flickr.com/photos/pandarine/37769107/ previous /a satellite image)
